wikipedia_page.main:
Frederick Sylvester North Douglas (8 February 1791 – 21 October 1819)  was an English actuary and politician.
He was the oldest son of Sylvester Douglas, 1st Baron Glenbervie, and his wife Lady Catherine Anne North, daughter of Frederick North, 2nd Earl of Guilford.He was educated at Westminster School, Christ Church, Oxford, and at Lincoln's Inn, before setting off on a grand tour from 1810 to 1812. On his return he wrote An Essay on Certain Points of Resemblance Between the Ancient and Modern Greeks.
He was elected at the 1812 general election as the Member of Parliament (MP) for Banbury, holding the seat until his death in 1819, aged 28.He was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society in 1817.

response: * Frederick Sylvester North Douglas (1791–1819), MP for Banbury

response: | Frederick Sylvester North Douglas||01/05/1817||4 February 1791 – 21 October 1819

She married Baron Glenbervie in 1789, several years before his elevation to the peerage. They had one son, Frederick Sylvester North Douglas, who sat in Parliament for Banbury, holding the seat until his death in 1819, aged 28, a few months after marrying Harriet Wrightson. Between 1808 and 1817, Lady Glenbervie was officially Mistress of the Robes to Caroline of Brunswick, Princess of Wales; between 1814 and 1820, the princess was living abroad.
